results.title: The Gourmet's Dilemma
results.creator_credit: Robert V Jenkins, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
A light hearted yet serious educational production highlighting to new migrants the strict quarantine precautions necessary against Foot and Mouth disease and other animal diseases being introduced into Australia. The film was originally presented with the options of Greek or Italian narration, we follow Nino and his family’s passage to Australia.
Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection

results.title: Golf in Australia
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Illustrates the wide popularity of golf in Australia, showing the variety of courses and outlining training schemes and other aspects of the sport. Concludes with scenes from professional tournaments.

results.title: Infected
results.material_description: video, circular screen, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Infected is a projected video installation about the nature of the physical body in the context of future technological possibilities, seen through dance and digitally manipulated imagery. The new bio-engineered body is still a sexual, stark, brutal, organic, pounding bloody system with ripping tendons. It is beautiful and repulsive, indulgent, curious, emotional, un/controlled, breeding, changing.

Gina Czarnecki is an artist originating from the UK whose films and installations have been exhibited widely across the UK and around the world. Infected continues her work around the visceral, biological and emotive body and its politics in relation to new technologies.

This video is made in collaboration with Iona Kewney, a Glasgow-based dance artist. It features a specially commissioned score by Fennesz, whose computer-manipulations of sounds derived from guitar and other acoustic sources have won him worldwide acclaim as one of the most innovative and important artists working in electronic music.

results.title: Goldtown
results.creator_credit: R. Maslyn Williams and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of Australia’s fabulous town with the “golden mile” - Kalgoorlie in Western Australia, a goldmining town in the midst of a forbidding desert where the water supply is piped hundreds of miles overland.

results.title: Geraldton
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
Geraldton, Western Australia, is a fast developing town as it is the major supply centre and port of the north of the state. A glimpse of the people, industries, such as building and crayfishing, and social life of Geraldton.

results.title: From the tropics to the snow
results.creator_credit: J Lee, R. Mason, Malcolm Otton, Stanley Hawes and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A tourist film of Australia. It is not a travelogue but a story combining humour with selling and entertainment with information; highlighting the difficulties of a producer, director and script-writer in the making of a short film which is to show all the tourist attractions of Australia. The film gently (and not so gently) laughs at all those aspects of the Australian way of life that are usually included in films about Australia, and also shows some of the not so well known attractions of the country. (Awards: Gold Award, Travel Category; Australian National Travel Association’s “Jedda Award”; Kodak Silver Award for colour photography, Australian Film Awards, 1965).

results.title: Freeway driving
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Skills of Defensive Driving”.
Emphasises the particular skills needed for safe use of freeways where road speed is greater than normal and driving dkills are different.

results.title: Five bells: sights and sounds of Sydney Harbour
results.creator_credit: Dean Semler, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Sydney Harbour, the most beautiful in the world, is celebrated in this lyrical documentary. Pre-dawn a memory of the Harbour’s convict past appears like a dream, but as the sun rises and the trawlers trek back with their cargo of prawns the Harbour comes to life in 1978. Australia’s multi-cultural society is epitomised in this film.

results.title: Fiji - legacies of empire
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Philip Robertson, Cinema Enterprises and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This series looks at the Pacific islands, the traditions associated with them and issues that pose problems to them. This particular film examines the different aspects of life in Fiji. It notes the opinions of a patriarch of the hard-working Indian population and explores the co-existence of Hindus and Moslems who own less than a fifth of the land. Camera by Dennis O’Rourke and Joe Pickering.
